posts.title: Book Club: Velvet Was the Night, Ep. 206
posts.text: Our hosts, Frank and Crystal, kicked off this episode with a chat about the new 'West Side Story' movie before talking about Silvia Moreno-Garcia's novel 'Velvet Was the Night,' one of NYPL"s Best Books of 2021.

posts.title: Our Cozy Book Club Episode!, Ep. 204
posts.text: What's a cozy book to you? Frank and Crystal discuss this and their cozy reads of the week—a celebrity memoir and a rom-com murder mystery.

posts.title: Bad Art Friend or Shared [Art] Experience?, Ep. 203
posts.text: In this episode, Frank discusses Lydia Millet's novel 'A Children's Bible,' and then he and Crystal dissect the viral article "Who Is the Bad Art Friend?"

posts.title: Book Club..."A Hot Rod of Energy"!, Ep. 202
posts.text: Our hosts, Frank and Crystal, tackled a supernatural horror read this month—Stephen Graham Jones's 'The Only Good Indians' which they found "pulse-pounding" and "psychologically disturbing." Spoiler: they both liked it, too.

posts.title: Coffee, Coffee, Coffee! (And Books!), Ep. 201
posts.text: In this episode, Frank and Crystal discuss Kazua Ishiguro's novel 'Klara and the Sun' and 'Half World,' a YA fantasy novel by Hiromi Goto.

posts.title: Celebrate International Podcast Day with The Librarian Is In!
posts.text: New to our podcast? Here are some of our favorites to get started with. Old fan? We hope you enjoy revisiting these episodes with Frank, Gwen, Rhonda, and Crystal!

posts.title: Book Club! And Our 200th Episode!
posts.text: In this episode, our hosts chose a book that they felt fit the theme of "Required Reading." Frank chose a classic—'Great Expectations'—while Crystal chose a graphic novel—'Blue Period'—about the struggles of life as an artist.

posts.title: Doris Day, Debbie Reynolds, and Survival Horror, Ep. 199
posts.text: In this episode, Frank and Crystal discuss 'Felon: Poems' by Reginald Dwayne Betts and the novel 'The Death of the Heart' by Elizabeth Bowen.

posts.title: Book Club: The Chosen and the Beautiful, Ep. 198
posts.text: In this episode Frank and Crystal discuss Nghi Vo's debut novel, an adaptation of 'The Great Gatsby'.

posts.title: Deluded Restraint or..., Ep. 197
posts.text: In this episode, Frank and Crystal talk about a teen superhero comic book and a celebrity-written work about beauty and aging.

posts.title: Book Club: The Meaning of Mariah Carey, Ep. 196
posts.text: This week Crystal and Frank broke with their track record of reading "very serious" novels to read a fun memoir by the well-known and VERY glamorous Mariah Carey.

posts.title: Clans and Communities, Ep. 195
posts.text: In this episode, our intrepid hosts discuss the novel 'Let's Get Back to the Party' by Zak Salih and the dystopian sci-fi book 'Trail of Lightening' by Rebecca Roanhorse.

posts.title: Book Club: Memorial by Bryan Washington, Ep. 194
posts.text: This week, listen to Frank and Crystal discuss Bryan Washington's debut novel set in Houston and Japan.

posts.title: A Military Phase? Or Is It Just Synergy? Ep. 193
posts.text: Join Frank and Crystal as they discuss the nonfiction book 'The Sacred Band: Three Hundred Theban Lovers Fighting to Save Greek Freedom' by James Romm and the graphic novel series 'Monstress' by Marjorie Liu.

posts.title: Insurrecto by Gina Apostol and GLITTER! Ep. 192
posts.text: Settle in as Frank and Crystal discuss this novel set in the Philippines.

posts.title: Frank's Franc and Crystal's Nickel!, Ep. 191
posts.text: In this episode, Frank read the novel 'Early Morning Riser' by Katherine Heiny, while Crystal chose a book of essays 'How to Slowly Kill Yourself and Others in America' by Kiese Laymon.

posts.title: Book Club: All Quiet on the Western Front, Ep. 190
posts.text: This week Frank and Crystal read a World War I novel about the stresses of war and re-entry to civilian life told from the perspective of a young German soldier.

posts.title: Rare Books! ASMR! A New Co-Host! Oh My!, Ep. 189
posts.text: This week we're excited for you to meet Frank's new co-host—Young Adult Librarian Crystal Chen. Frank devoured a recommendation from a listener, 'The Waitress Was New' by Dominique Fabre. Crystal kicks off with 'The Magic Fish,' a graphic novel by Trung Le Nguyen. And, play along with Frank as he tries to ace Crystal's ASMR quiz!

posts.title: Rhonda's Last Episode! Ep. 188
posts.text: In this episode, our hosts discuss Virginia Woolf's 'The Waves,' Leesa Cross Smith's 'This Close to Okay,' and we bid a fond farewell to Rhonda (sniff.)

posts.title: Book Club: Autobiography of Red, Ep. 187
posts.text: It's a novel, it's a poem—it's both. Join us as Frank and Rhonda discuss this work by Anne Carson from our 125 Books We Love list.

posts.title: Searching For Meaning: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 186
posts.text: This week Rhonda and Frank walked their own reading paths and then shared their impressions with each other. Coincidentally, they both picked books published in 1946—"The Street" by Ann Petry and "Man's Search for Meaning" by Viktor Frankl.

posts.title: Book Club: The Hound of the Baskervilles, Ep. 185
posts.text: This week Frank and Rhonda stroll the English moors taking in a Sherlock Holmes mystery. They're also joined by YA librarian Joe Pascullo who shares some of his favorite Young Adult reads from 2020.

posts.title: The Librarian Is In: What is Virtue? Ep. 184
posts.text: This week our hosts chose books on opposite ends of the genre spectrums—Frank dove into some Plato, while Rhonda picked up a crime noir novel.

posts.title: Book Club: The Stories of John Cheever, Ep. 183
posts.text: This week Frank and Rhonda discuss one of the books on our 125 NYC Books We Love list, 'The Stories of John Cheever'. They particularly home in on the themes of the loneliness and rigidity of suburban life that Cheever explores.

posts.title: New Year, Same Us (Yay!), Ep. 182
posts.text: An hour of musical theater references, interesting books, and great conversation!

posts.title: Book Club: Bodega Dreams, Ep. 181
posts.text: In this episode, Frank and Rhonda chat about resolutions (or a lack of) for the new year and then discuss the novel 'Bodega Dreams' by Ernesto Quiñonez.

posts.title: Bodega Dreams and Holiday Themes!, Ep. 180
posts.text: This week Frank and Rhonda read different books and fill the other in. Frank read the novel 'Mexican Gothic' by Silvia Moreno-Garcia and Rhonda read the memoir 'Haben: The Deafblind Woman Who Conquered Harvard Law' by Haben Girma.

posts.title: Book Club and Babs!, Ep. 179
posts.text: This week Frank and Rhonda get delightfully off track and gush about their love of Barbra Streisand. Then they move on to discuss American Primitive, a book of poems by Mary Oliver.

posts.title: Fiction...and More Fiction! Ep. 178
posts.text: Join Frank and Rhonda as they discuss 'Memoirs of Hadrian' by Marguerite Yorcenar and the short story "The Comet" which may be W.E.B. DuBois' only science fiction story.

posts.title: Book Club: The Parable of the Sower, Ep. 177
posts.text: This week Rhonda and Frank battle against the sounds of New York (construction, fire alarms, and drilling—oh my!) while they discuss Octavia Butler's allegorical science fiction novel.

posts.title: Have You Gotten Lost in a Good Book Lately?, Ep. 176
posts.text: This week our hosts, Frank and Rhonda, talk about 'The Haunting of Bly Manor', the novel 'The Map and the Territory', and the memoir 'All Boys Aren't Blue'.

posts.title: Book Club: The Turn of the Screw, Ep. 175
posts.text: Whether you had a chance to read the book or not, we think you'll agree that this week's episode is a fun listen.

posts.title: Is Fall Here Yet?!, Ep. 174
posts.text: This week Frank and Rhonda get into a fall mood and talk about the books The Black Prince and The Changelings.

posts.title: Book Club: And Then There Were None, Ep. 173
posts.text: This week Rhonda and Frank read 'And Then There Were None' by Agatha Christi and discuss cancel culture, the 'Saw' movies, and "dun-dun-dun" music cues.

posts.title: "Librarianing" Ourselves in Real Time!, Ep. 172
The World May Not Require Us, But At Least We Have Our Books!, Ep. 171
Book Club: 'An Extraordinary Union', Ep.170
posts.text: Is it hot in here, or is it just the steamy romance between Elle and Malcolm in our latest book club read?

posts.title: When Our Interests and Book Picks Collide, Ep. 169
posts.text: This week Frank and Rhonda discuss the novels 'Such a Fun Age', 'Passing" and much more.

posts.title: Book Club: 'Between the World and Me' by Ta-Nehisi Coates, Ep. 168
posts.text: Frank and Rhonda discuss this impactful book which appears on the Schomburg Center's Black Liberation Reading List.

posts.title: TRANSforming the Literary Landscape, Ep. 167
posts.text: Rhonda and Frank chat with children's librarian Ellen MacInnis to discuss the TRANSform NYPL project and pass along recommendations from the Trans and Gender Non Conforming book list.

posts.title: Trying to Figure Out How We Got Here, Ep. 166
posts.text: This week Rhonda and Frank check in with each other about the world's events, how they're holding up, and discuss their recent personal reading selections.

posts.title: June Book Club: The Librarian Is In, Ep. 165
posts.text: This week Frank and Rhonda discuss 'The Argonauts' by Maggie Nelson.

posts.title: Wilkommen: The Librarian Is In, Ep 164
posts.text: This week Frank and Rhonda discuss the books Nothing to See Here by Kevin Wilson and The Postman Always Rings Twice by James Cain.

posts.title: May Book Club: Train Dreams: The Librarian Is In, Ep 163
posts.text: Do you find yourself dreaming of getting away? Get away for a bit with Rhonda and Frank.

posts.title: How Y'all Doin'?: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep.162
posts.text: Today, Frank & Rhonda talk about what they've been reading at home.

posts.title: Book Club: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 161
posts.text: Frank and Rhonda go deep on Flannery O'Connor's 'A Good Man is Hard to Find'

posts.title: The Librarian is (Hanging) In (There): The Librarian Is In, Ep.160
posts.text: Frank and Rhonda are coming to you from their respective homes as they practice social distancing and try to stay sane!

posts.title: Machines Like Me? Monsters Like You!: The Librarian Is In, Ep.159
posts.text: Frank and Rhonda discuss a graphic novel and a novel with an alternate history timeline.

posts.title: February Book Club: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 158
posts.text: This week Frank and Rhonda discuss Giovanni's Room by James Baldwin.

posts.title: We're Baaaack!: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 157
posts.text: Frank and Rhonda pick favorites from the 125 Books We Love list.

posts.title: Walk the Windswept Moors: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 156
posts.text: For the last episode of 2019, Gwen surprises Frank by reading one of his all time favorite books, Frank delves into the world of Trust Exercise and Gwen shares a personal announcement. Stay warm on those windswept moors everybody, and we'll see you in 2020!

posts.title: Wallow with Me: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 155
posts.text: Come stare moodily out a lonely window with us! Frank falls into a book trance after reading a French novel with a double meaning in its title, and Gwen unpacks a heartbreaker about a woman who leaves Jamaica for Brooklyn.

posts.title: Frozen Solid: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 154
posts.text: Frank is feeling all the feelings about a book of experimental prose poetry, Gwen is charmed by a semi-autobiographical YA story, and everyone has "Let It Go" stuck in their heads now. You're welcome!

posts.title: When Pushkin Comes to Shove: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 153
posts.text: Frank reads 19th-century Russian verse out loud for a solid two minutes. What more could you want in this world? Plus: Ben Platt, call us. Maybe.

posts.title: Anita Brookner and Dorothy Parker Walk into a Bar... The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 152
posts.text: Your hosts wax rhapsodic about two of their mainstay favorite authors. Plus: Gwen takes "cozy intellectual" suggestions from a listener's email and Frank discovers a YouTube celebrity crush.

posts.title: Cuckoo for Overdue: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 151
posts.text: Third time's the charm! Gwen and Frank join the fine folks from the Overdue podcast to discuss Ken Kesey's 1962 novel, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.

posts.title: Cozy Intellectualism and/or Baby Marginalia: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 150
posts.text: We all love libraries, but what books do you just NEED to own? Frank coins a new genre, Gwen falls for a book about mistakes, and they both share some deep thoughts about the Oxford comma.

posts.title: Life-Changing Lessons: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 149
posts.text: Book synergy abounds with two titles that explore the sometimes dark, sometimes funny, sometimes supernatural relationship between parents and children. Plus, a listener question about "leisure reading" proves to be more complicated than it first seems.

posts.title: Books on the Subway: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 148
posts.text: This week, it's Frank and Gwen's turn in the hot seat. They recently joined Hollie & Rosy on the Books on the Subway Podcast for a discussion about all things library and books, so we're bringing you their episode this week! Make sure to check them out at booksonthesubway.com.

posts.title: Dragons and Robots: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 147
posts.text: A look at how some libraries reflect the communities they're a part of through their special collections. Plus, Gwen's son weighs in on a children's book with some very un-scary dragons and Frank dives into some mind-bending stories about alternate realities and the nature of consciousness.

posts.title: Stonewall 50: The Sound of Memory
posts.text: The Stonewall Riots were a flash point in LGBTQ history. After the riots that took place at the Stonewall Inn in June 1969, the LGBTQ civil rights movement went from handfuls of pioneering activists to a national movement mobilizing thousands.

posts.title: Before Stonewall
posts.text: This week on Library Talks, Aidan Flax-Clark welcomes co-host Jason Baumann, Assistant Director for Collection Development and Coordinator of Humanities and coordinator of the Library’s LGBTQ iniative for a special episode about queer life before the Stonewall Riots

posts.title: Marlon James Gets Nerdy with Kevin Young
posts.text: In a special interview with Schomburg Director, Kevin Young, James talks about his newest book "Black Leopard, Red Wolf" the first of his epic fantasy trilogy that blends ancient African mythology with history.

posts.title: A History of the Queer Press
posts.text: In the footsteps of queer media luminaries of the 60s and 70s, WNYC podcast hosts Kathy Tu and Tobin Low interview Gay Liberation Front founding members to discuss their legacy.

posts.title: Erin Lee Carr and Ta-Nehisi Coates Remember David Carr
posts.text: Documentary filmmaker Erin Lee Carr remembers her father, journalist David Carr, in a moving new memoir. One of her father’s mentees, Ta-Nehisi Coates, joins Carr to discuss the legacy her father left.

posts.title: How Robert Caro Writes About Power and the Powerless, Ep. 266
posts.text: "The Power Broker" author Robert Caro talks about his writing process, researching at NYPL and what he's learned about power.

posts.title: Breaking New Ground with Dr. Carla Hayden and Tracy K. Smith, Ep. 265
posts.text: Dr. Carla Hayden, the 14th Librarian of Congress talks with Tracy K. Smith, the 22nd Poet Laureate of the United States about their work, the future of Black librarianship and the democratization of libraries.

posts.title: Jill Abramson and Jane Mayer's Insider Take on the News
posts.text: The former executive editor of the The New York Times tells the story of the news industry in her new book "Merchants of Truth."

posts.title: Eliza Griswold Uncovers the Human Cost of Fracking
posts.text: The immersion journalist on her Pulitzer Prize-winning book "Amity and Prosperity: One Family and the Fracturing of America."

posts.title: Shane Bauer's Undercover Reporting from Inside a Private Prison, Ep. 262
posts.text: The recent Bernstein Award winner discusses the making of this book and his personal difficulties balancing his identities as a prison guard and reporter.

posts.title: Emily Bazelon and Stacey Abrams talk Criminal Justice Reform, Ep. 261
posts.text: In her new book, "Charged", journalist Emily Bazelon argues that prosecutors play an outside role in mass incarceration, from choosing the charge to setting bail to determining the plea bargain. She discussed the issue with Stacey Abrams, a lawyer, novelist, and politician who campaigned for criminal justice reform in Georgia in 2018.

posts.title: Bending Reality with G. Willow Wilson, Ep. 260
posts.text: G. Willow Wilson is a critically acclaimed novelist and co-creator of the first Muslim superhero with their own Marvel comic book series.

posts.title: Janet Napolitano Explains Homeland Security with Joe Biden, Ep. 259
posts.text: Few people understand the state of our national security as well as Janet Napolitano and Joe Biden.

posts.title: Still Cringing After 'Cat Person', Ep. 258
posts.text: The author of the viral long form fiction piece has a new debut collection of short stories that are sure to make you squirm.

posts.title: Paperback Crushin', Ep. 257
posts.text: Bustle editor and writer Gabrielle Moss makes the case for why YA fiction of the '80s and '90s shouldn't be overlooked.

posts.title: Frankenstein: Our Dark Mirror, Ep. 256
posts.text: A special podcast episode that takes a deep dive into Mary Shelley's classic story and how it reflects our darkest fears.

posts.title: Marilynne Robinson: Liberalism and American Tradition Pt. I and Pt. II, Ep. 254 and 255
posts.text: The Pulitzer Prize-winning poet delivered this special lecture presented by The Cullman Center.

posts.title: How to Make Black Lives Matter at School, Ep. 253
posts.text: Despite the fact that New York City is one of the most diverse places in the country, our school system is among the most segregated.

posts.title: Envisioning 'A People's Future of the United States', Ep. 252
posts.text: Author Victor LaValle moderates a discussion with four speculative fiction writers about this new collection of stories.

posts.title: NYPL Podcasts: Five Episodes to Listen to This Black History Month
posts.text: To celebrate Black History Month, NYPL Podcasts compiled a few favorite episodes from the past year featuring influential Black authors, educators, and activists.

posts.title: The Banished Immortal, Ep. 250
posts.text: The National Book Award–winning writer highlights the many lives and legends of one of China’s greatest poets, Li Bai.

posts.title: Seeing and Being Seen in Sally Wen Mao's 'Oculus' , Ep. 249
posts.text: Poets Sally Wen Mao and Jenny Xie discuss Mao’s new poetry collection, Asian American representation in film, technology, and archival research.

posts.title: Maria Popova's A Velocity of Being, Ep. 248
posts.text: Maria Popova & Claudia Bedrick curated an anthology of letters and original illustrations by 121 of the most interesting and inspiring culture-makers alive today.

posts.title: Satirizing America in 'Friday Black', Ep. 247
posts.text: Author Nana Kwame Adjeh-Brenyah talk about his debut collection of short stories with writer Mychal Denzel Smith

posts.title: Introducing Ourselves: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 1
posts.text: On the very first episode of NYPL's brand-new podcast, Frank and Gwen talk about book shame, their reading origin stories, the glory of Jefferson Market, and why some young people are saying "swell" without irony.
